Yes, there have been numerous studies on the impact of diversity in policing on community relations and community policing efforts. Here are a few examples:

- A study published in the Journal of Criminal Justice found that a police force's racial composition was significantly related to its level of community-oriented policing. The study found that departments with higher proportions of minority officers tended to have a greater commitment to community policing and better relationships with the community.

- Another study published in Police Quarterly found that police officers who were more racially and culturally diverse were more likely to have positive attitudes towards community policing and to engage in community policing activities.

- The International Association of Chiefs of Police conducted a study of community policing practices in several U.S. cities, and found that departments with diverse workforces had better relationships with the communities they served and were more effective at reducing crime and disorder.

While there have been some mixed findings in studies assessing the relationship between diversity in policing and community relations, there is a growing body of research that supports the idea that diversity in police departments can help build trust and improve communication with diverse communities.
